title: Will Dilma Rousseff cease to be President of Brazil before 1 January 2017?
preds:
According to the general news and GJP consensus. 
Vote was done today!

This is an update not a forecast. 
The party is over, figuratively and in reality, for her in this question.   
She was removed from office earlier today.  Brazil's President Rousseff ousted from office by Senate

Michel Temer confirmed as new president after 61 of 81 senators back Rousseff’s removal from office amid economic decline and bribery scandal Brazil’s first female president Dilma Rousseff has been thrown out of office by the country’s corruption-tainted senate after a gruelling impeachment trial that ends 13 years of Workers’ party rule.

According to multiple sources Dilma Rousseff has now been impeached with 61 senators voting for her impeachment. Although she can appeal to Brazil's highest court, I do not see that as being very likely. I now increase my percentage by 12%.
She lost. There was 61 votes against her, 7 more than needed to remove her from office.

All over. Brazil's Senate Prepares For Final Vote On Dilma Rousseff's Impeachment
http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/08/31/492064070/brazils-senate-prepares-for-final-vote-on-dilma-rousseffs-impeachment

Going up 1 from 99% to 100%. Date: 31. August 2016 um 12:02:44 MESZ Subject: Brazil Senate Impeachment D Day Comment: Beginning 11:00am Brazilian time this morning, the voting session begins. Two senators speak in favor & two against impeachment w/ five minutes being provided to each. Thereafter, nominal voting in electronic panels will be cast. (Footnote 1) Certain Brazilian media sources claim there are ALREADY at least 54 votes to impeach, the minimum number required to carry the Senate motion according to the Brazilian Constitution (2). Caveat on Credibility although it does come from a well followed Brazilian source.  Interestingly, the previously undecided Conservative Senator Antonio Valadares PSB SE signaled his vote to impeach on his presentation yesterday claiming Rousseff had violated various laws which are subject to the impeachment procedure.(3) Conclusion:  PLEASE note : above-mentioned is intended merely as a personal reference in case Rousseff is acquitted, to go back and ask myself "what was I thinking".  Rather, what has been fascinating about this "sorry State of Affairs" GJ Q will be  a learning experience - for future reference - in financial terms. The contrarian style I carry as baggage through life  w/ me, has seen this impeachment process play out as the final act ...of a bubble of a so-called emerging market...that has been burst.  An impeachment, SHOULD there be one, from my perspective, represents an OPPORTUNITY to take advantage of in terms of boom and bust cycles. BRIC ( Brazil, Russia, India, China) no longer is a well known term today. Rather, "IN" is ---- FANG ---- ( Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflex, Google) in the U.S.  Booms & busts tend to have if not identical, then rather similar characteristics.  Brazil, is arguably at the worst  stage of this BUST cycle. Add Impeachment to the cost of the Olympics &, the extreme low point of this cycle is now definable.  In the U.S., for example during the Nixon impeachment proceedings, economic conditions were extreme, as well. Thereafter, post 1974 stock market crash triggered by the collapse of Bretton Woods a major recession took hold. GDP was down 3%, unemployment jumped to 9%. http://www.dividend.com/dividend-education/the-dow-30-a-look-into-the-last-five-recessions/ Both represent interesting lessons & opportunity. There are certain elements in Brazil that suggest, for contrarians, it is time to take a long hard look. Currency depreciation. Brazil is also the most significantly underweighted Country segment for most institutional investors worldwide, for years now.  It sounds strange to say, but another NAIL  in the coffin of this Brazilian BEAR market may well be taken this afternoon/tonight by those Senators who decide on the fate of Ms. Dilma Rousseff. Doesn't seem like her testimony yesterday may a difference or brought her new friends.  Not that it was expected to do so.  The Brazilian senate is hearing final arguments today and may vote tonight or tomorrow. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-08-30/from-guerrilla-to-impeachment-the-dilma-rousseff-story Globo says only 20 Senators are against Dilma's impeachment and that at this stage, it is very unlikely anyone will change their vote. She needs 54 Senators on her side out of 81.   Temer, Dilma's VP and current interim president, did not attend the proceedings and the Brazilian press says he is playing the nothing is happening card, showing he has no reason at all to be concerned.  Some press reported he has phoned in senators to make sure their position for impeachment stands.  http://oglobo.globo.com/brasil/senado-define-futuro-de-dilma-rousseff-nesta-terca-feira-20015986#ixzz4IrJUDMPV

Impeachment proceedings are almost always political decisions with a thin veneer of law rather than legal decisions.  That's why they are given to political rather than legal bodies to conduct.  All things considered, this is probably sensible. Temer may be only slightly better than Dilma, but just now he is the status quo.  The honourable Senators, a terrific percentage of whom are also under investigation, are highly likely to favour ephemeral stability over ephemeral brouhaha.  She's out.

The vote is imminent (sorry--upcoming).  A surprise is not expected--but then, it wouldn't be a surprise, would it?  Tchau, Dilma.

I haven't been able to get on in a while but now I am reposting. Since my last update, things have changed a lot regarded Rousseff. The trial will come to a close this week and according to BBC, 52 senators have declared that they will vote for her impeachment. This means that only two more out of the 29 senators will be needed to confirm her impeachment. With this I increase my percentage by 40% leaving me at 69%. Also, because the majority of Brazil is against Rousseff, even if she survives the vote and is reinstated, there is a possibility that she could resign afterward. She has already stated that she would bring a reelection sooner than usual so as to remove the corruption from the government. With this I increase my percentage by 15%. Regardless, I will be waiting for Dilma's defense speech and the reaction of the senators to see if any other changes are necessary.

Increasing from 35%, based on the comments following my last post a week ago.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/273245 It seems increasingly likely that Dilma Rousseff could avoid impeachment. 54 out of 81 Senators will have to find her guilty, whereas the vote to start a trial was just 55-22. In her best case scenario, only two Senators would have to change their mind - which seems quite feasible. In the worst case, she would need six more Senators to back her, i.e. 28 in all, to deny her opponents any chance of a two thirds majority (possible, but somewhat more difficult for her). I'd guess she has a 60% chance of avoiding impeachment especially as the opposition is itself in turmoil (Cunha resignation etc). However, she has indicated that she'll call fresh elections if acquitted. As pointed out by @scholarandcat, term limits would bar her from standing in such an election. The question then is whether the election process would be completed in 2016. @praedico has noted that Brazilian presidential elections are typically held in October, and the new President is inaugurated on 01 January, It's thus possible that Dilma won't cease to be President before 01 January 2017 if she (1) isn't found guilty by the Senate, and (2) either doesn't call an early election, or does call it in October and her successor is inaugurated on 01 Jan 2017 in accordance with previous practice. My guess is that there's at least a 40% chance of Scenario 2 occurring. The chance of her remaining President would thus be 0.6*0.4 = 24%

https://www.yahoo.com/sports/news/rio-state-declares-financial-emergency-requests-funding-olympics-005430624--oly.html RIO DE JANEIRO (Reuters) - Rio de Janeiro’s governor declared a state of financial emergency Friday and requested federal funds to help fulfill obligations for public services during the Olympics that start Aug. 5.  Emergency measures are needed to avoid “a total collapse in public security, health, education, transport and environmental management,” a decree in the state’s Official Gazette said. The state’s revenue, largely tied to the petroleum industry, slumped in the last two years as global oil prices collapsed.  The announcement followed this week’s visit to Rio by Brazil’s Interim President Michel Temer, who said the federal government would ensure all obligations are met for a successful Games. Rio is expecting about 500,000 foreign visitors during the Olympics, which has coincided with Brazil’s worst recession since the 1930s and a political crisis that last month led to the suspension of President Dilma Rousseff. “The state’s financial emergency in no way delays the delivery of Olympic projects and the promises assumed by the city of Rio,” Mayor Eduardo Paes said on Twitter. He also underscored that legacy construction projects, with the exception of an 8.79 billion-real expansion of Rio’s metro that is expected to be finished just days before the Games open, are the responsibility of the city and that most have been completed.  The local organizing committee for the Games said the state’s fiscal situation did not impact its actual running of the Olympics, which relies entirely on private funds. While the majority of Olympic infrastructure costs have been spread across city, state and federal budgets, with some financing from private companies, the state is responsible for most day-to-day security and health services in Rio. The financial pinch resulted in a 30-percent cut in the state’s security budget - just as Rio has seen a jump in homicides and assaults in recent months, raising concerns about safety ahead of the Olympics. The state of Rio expects a budget deficit of over 19 billion reais ($5.56 billion) this year as spending planned before oil prices fell outstrips revenue that is tumbling during Brazil’s recession. Rio state’s debt has been downgraded several times.  On Wednesday, Fitch Ratings downgraded Rio’s debt rating to ‘B-’ from 'B+’, saying the state was suffering “a fast-deteriorating liquidity position."  Since late last year, the state has been forced to delay pension and salary payments and shutter some schools and hospitals, where crucial supplies, including medicines and syringes, are lacking.  Brazil is also facing an outbreak of the Zika virus, which has been linked to the birth defect microcephaly in which babies are born with abnormally small heads frequently associated with developmental issues.  (Reporting by Paulo Prada, Stephen Eisenhammer and Brad Brooks; editing by Richard Chang and Andrew Hay)

Since the start of the New Republic in Brazil, out of the 5 presidents (not including Rousseff), only 1 has been impeached so my baseline estimate is at 20%. Why would Rousseff be impeached?  Rousseff’s approval ratings have dropped tremendously over the past two years as Brazil has slipped into economic turmoil, but that doesn’t exactly have anything to do with impeachment so I don’t change my probability.  Rousseff has now been suspended from office and awaits her trial. Rousseff’s trial has not started, but she has been suspended from office and from that date she has 180 days to be convicted of corruption, more specifically, covering holes on the national budget by shifting funds.
	With that I increase my probability by 2-5% because she is being accused of violating fiscal laws. 
If she is not convicted by those 180 days then she will assume her position again. Because she has now made it this far into the last stage of the impeachment process, I increase my estimate 30% putting me at 55%. 
	I say this because there is now only a two-thirds vote that stands between her and her position, and I feel that by making it through all of other phases of the impeachment process, there is not as much inhibiting her impeachment.  In order for her to be convicted, 54 out of the 81 senators need to vote “yes”. If at least 54 senators all vote yes arbitrarily, there is a 1% chance of that happening so I increase my estimate by one. 56% Obviously, senators’ decisions are not arbitrary as they are all part of a political party and therefore they will vote based off of their party ideals, etc… Of the four major parties in power, PT has 11 seats in the senate, PMDB has 18, PSDB has 11, and DEM has 4.
	Because Cunha is one of Rousseff’s largest critics, I think that most of PMDB senators would vote for the impeachment which is 18 out of the 54 needed. 
	PTB did not support Rousseff in the elections so I would guess that it’s 3 senators would vote for impeachment. That is now 21 1of 54 needed. 
	PSDB is known as an antagonist to the worker party which adds 11 more senators putting it at 32 of the 54 needed. 
	PP supports the impeachment of Rousseff so that adds another 6 senators, adding up to 38 of 54 needed. 
	DEM is in the Change Brazil coalition which is a rival against Rousseff’s coalition, so I would assume that it’s senators vote for impeachment, adding 4, which leaves 42 of 54 needed. 
	I don’t have the time right now to look up more of this data but assuming I am correct with the above data, I don’t think it would be that difficult for those against Rousseff to recruit a few more senators to vote for the impeachment. 
	Thus, I raise my probability by 10%, yielding 66%.  Why Rousseff wouldn’t be impeached? It’s possible that the trial does not finish before the 180 days in which case she would go back into office. With this I lower my probability by 2-5% If Rousseff is voted to be impeached, she can appeal the trial. This would have to be on the basis of legal violations. Quite a lot of people seem really certain about this. However, I am not really convinced, and even after a long search, cannot find good data that would help me decide this. The problems are manyfold. First of all, the timeframe. January 1st, 2017, is not really far off. Based on history, we can say that Impeachment trials are lengthy and cumbersome affairs. They are not cut and dry trials like murder cases with tons of DNA evidence and a written confession. The second is the votes. Yes, congress and senate voted to suspend her. Now, within 180 days, a trial must take place. However, this trial is not going to be conducted by the senate (at least, not to my knowledge), but instead by the judicial branch. I have to admit I don't think this question is worth it digging into all the legal stuff. In addition, I am not certain just how corrupt the legal system is and how easily a verdict can be bought. That means that there is a good chance that Rousseff may yet weather the storm until 1st of January 2017. The outcome will be dependent on too many factors to judge correctly: Whether something unexpected happens, whether she panics and just runs away, whether she is really guilty of the charges laid against her, how quickly the court will come to a conclusion, how determined her enemies are to get her out of power, how many allies she can amass in that time, etc. etc. etc. So, for now, I am assigning a simple 50:50. If anyone has any comments or thinks I have something completely wrong, please let me know. This is a question that will need lots of updates depending on the news.

So far, everyone seems way too certain about this, and I apologise in advance for this ramble but I have now spent far more time on this than I intended to, and didn't make the effort to edit.  It’s very difficult to set a base rate here, there has only been one impeachment in Brazil (1992, successful). There was one impeachment of a president in Paraguay (2012), which was also successful. Both were significantly closer to unanimous than the initial impeachment of Rousseff.  There have been two impeachments of US Presidents, Johnson and Clinton, both were highly acrimonious, partisan proceedings and resulted in acquittal. Nixon resigned before Congress had the chance to impeach him, I think we can safely assume he would have been found guilty, and I would say there is a good case to add him to the sample. Impeachment processes are, I believe, relatively similar across all these countries. It is rather time-consuming to get the data for this. I don’t really know what to conclude here, other than my impression is that the successful impeachments (especially Brazil 1992 and Paraguay 2012, and if we were to include Nixon) were much closer to unanimous. I would be very interested if anyone could put together a better dataset for impeachments of heads of states in countries with similar processes to Brazil. Verdict: without doing much more work, I can’t really have anything other than an extremely weak prior.   Switching to the Inside View: I am not sure the previous successful impeachment in Brazil tells us much – impeachment vote was significantly more overwhelming, President resigned before being found guilty (which he was, after resignation). You can read about it here (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fernando_Collor_de_Mello#Corruption_charges_and_impeachment), but I struggle to fund anything useful. As for these proceedings, I think there is a 99% probability there will be a trial, starting very soon. Timeframe: there is a time limit of 180 days after impeachment before the suspension of office ends. So it seems like the timeframe for 2017 is definitely on... but, let me quote para 2 of Article 86 of the Brazilian Constitution "Paragraph 2 - If, after a period of one hundred and eighty days, the trial has not been concluded, the suspension of the President shall cease *without prejudice to the normal progress of the proceeding*." (*My emphasis*) The 180 days appears not to be a deadline for the end of the trial, just the suspension from office. So the trial could conceivably continue into 2017, especially if it is uncertain whether they have the votes. How likely is this to happen? I wouldn't want to bet on much less than 5-10%. Conditional on Rousseff being found guilty in a trial, I'm going to start with a 93% chance it happens in 2016.  How likely is she to be found guilty? I've taken the 81 senate seats (per the list here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Senate), and taken the % of votes to impeach by party in the Chamber of Deputies from here (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impeachment_process_against_Dilma_Rousseff),assigning a 90% probability for voting to impeach by the three “non-aligned” given two of them recently left PT (Rousseff’s Party) and one PDT (another left wing Party that was giving support to Rousseff at the time) on seemingly acrimonious terms and one of them indeed is responsible for providing evidence against Rousseff  (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-36211526), and a 70% probability to the PTC member who is recently ex-PTB, of which 70% voted to impeach. Doing all that gets you to 58.9 votes, or c.5 more than the required 2/3. That seems very tight to me, but much more likely they have the votes than not. For now, I’m going with 80%. Multiplied with 93% it happens in the forecast period, with 99% probability of there being a trial, that’s c.74%.  Other factors: she could resign/flee. I consider it highly, highly unlikely she would do so unless she was near-certain of being found guilty – so mostly this is co-extensive with “guilty” having the votes, and I’ll add 1% onto the forecast for this - so 75%.      She could also be assassinated, or something else I haven’t thought of that is ‘outside the model’. Another 1% for that puts me up to 76%.  Despite the chain of reasoning, my forecast is currently still substantially driven by the probability of there being the votes to find her guilty, but absent more information it just seems like it is much closer than a 90%+ probability would imply.  Comments extremely welcome. EDIT: The consensus seemed to come down quite a lot while I was writing this brain-splurge, when I started thinking about this I was seeing a lot of 90%+
